title: Buddhist Priest's Robe (Kesa) with Decoration of Phoenixes (Hô-ô) and Flowers amid Clouds
description: A Buddhist priest's robe known in Japan as a kesa (Sanskrit, kasaya), this rectangular garment is made up of mulitple pieces of the same cloth that together form a patchwork of rectangles and squares framed within a border. The fabric is a pale green-blue silk decorated with long-tailed phoenixes, flowers, and golden clouds. The phoenixes and flowers were embroidered utilizing multicolored silk threads; selected outlines of motifs were embroidered with gold threads. The clouds were hand-painted on using gold pigments.
creditline: Harvard Art Museums/Arthur M. Sackler Museum, The Louis V. Ledoux Collection; Gift of Mrs. L. Pierre Ledoux in memory of her husband
medium: Pale green-blue silk with cloud motifs painted in gold pigment; additional motifs embroidered in polychrome silk and gold threads
provenance:
[Roland Koscherak, NY, by 1932], sold; to Louis V. Ledoux Collection, New York (1932-1948), by descent; to his son L. Pierre Ledoux, New York (1948-2001), by inheritance; to his widow Joan F. Ledoux, New York, (2001-2013), gift; to Harvard Art Museums, 2013.
